there are certain uh people that I read
is have have read over the years who I
found particularly helpful to return to
uh when I'm thinking about say these
identity questions John Stewart Mill
comes to mind I mean I I I think that on
Liberty is a book that repays endless uh
rereading and I most years I read some
of it with some students uh at some
Level under graduate or graduate because
I because I find it so rewarding and I
learn new things each time I look at it
um so I think there are there are sort
of particular philosophers that I I find
inspiring and helpful in that way not
that I agree with everything he says I'm
not a million uh but I'm someone who
finds Mill endlessly rewarding to
read um in general in philosophy I think
one of the the ideas that has actually
proved most useful to me is an idea is a
relatively technical idea uh that comes
from the work of philosopher that most
people haven't heard of called Frank
Ramsey who died when young in the in
England in the
1930s who who was a colleague of
Russells and Moors and keeses and and so
on and who who laid the foundations
among other things for much modern
thinking in many fields not just
philosophy he was one of the first
people to work out the the way of
thinking about um how people should take
decisions it's called decision Theory
which is at the foundation of much
modern economics for example
I think very often it's helpful rather
than as it were trying to say what it is
for a
concept to apply in a direct way it's
it's often helpful to say no let's ask
the different question let's ask what
would it take to persuade me that it
applies to a particular thing and what
would I what would it be legitimate to
do if it did apply you can think of say
some of the work that I did on Race as
applying this basic Ramsey idea to to
the race concept asking not what is race
but how do we use it how do we decide
that somebody is of a certain race what
are our practices of of ascribing racial
labels and then um what do we do when
we've ascribed a racial label what what
is what follows from that and then you
can ask the question which aspects of
this set of practices can be
justified uh if our practices of a
scription presuppose false biology then
they can't be justified uh if our ways
of treating people on the B of race are
inconsistent with uh fundamental moral
principles then those ways of reading
people can't be justified and so we must
revise and reform the concept both to
make it intellectually sound to make it
consistent with what our best
understanding is of reality and also to
make it morally or normatively sound so
that we can make it consistent with our
best understanding of of morality and of
what it is to lead a good and
responsible life I don't like
characterizing philosophers in term
terms of their ancestry their
affiliation within philosophy but if I
had to if you put a gun to my head and
said you have to do that I'd say I'm a
I'm a ramse and and I'm a million those
are the two philosophers who I think
have had the most influence on me
